Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Everlasting Security for Disadvantaged Wireless Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops techniques to provide information-theoretic secrecy for messages transmitted in a wireless communication system for the challenging scenario where an eavesdropper receives a stronger signal than the desired recipient: for example, the eavesdropper might be significantly closer to the transmitter than the intended receiver. The approach considered in this project starts with the transmitter and intended receiver sharing an ephemeral cryptographic key, which the transmitter then employs to intentionally distort the transmitted signal. With knowledge of the key, the intended receiver has a significant advantage over the eavesdropper in reducing this intentional distortion before analog-to-digital conversion and the recording of the signal. Even if the eavesdropper obtains the key at some later time, the nonlinearity of the analog-to-digital conversion and the fact that non-linear operators are not necessarily commutative implies the eavesdropper cannot remove the intentional distortion. In this manner, information-theoretic secrecy is obtained. The project will consider methods of maximizing the rate of secret communications through this technique. First, approaches to narrowband systems that employ an additive jamming signal based on the shared key will be developed. Next, attention will turn to wideband systems, where the shared key can be used to additionally hide the band of operation of the transmitter, hence further inhibiting the eavesdropper. Critical to the consideration of wideband systems is considering broad classes of emerging receiver capabilities for the eavesdropper. Finally, the project will build on recent analytic techniques to consider the provisioning of secrecy in network scenarios where the interaction of the transmissions of different system nodes must be considered.

The protection of messages in wireless communication systems from eavesdropping has clear societal benefit. Standardly employed cryptographic approaches make critical assumptions on the current and future computational capabilities of the eavesdropper, who may record a transmitted message and attempt to break it over a long time period; hence, information-theoretic techniques are of interest for the provisioning of everlasting secrecy. However, information-theoretic secrecy generally requires an advantage for the intended recipient over the eavesdropper, which, per above, is difficult to guarantee in wireless communication systems, leading to a significant risk that the contents of a message will be immediately compromised. The technique considered here exploits the strengths of both cryptographic approaches, which are not susceptible to an eavesdropper close to the transmitter, and information-theoretic approaches, which provide everlasting secrecy if the required advantage is available for the recipient over the eavesdropper. The result is a method with the potential to provide significant broad societal benefit through a technique for robust everlasting secrecy in wireless communication systems. The project also has a significant educational theme, providing both outreach to K-12 students and significant project and research opportunities to a diverse set of University of Massachusetts students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The protection of message content from eavesdropping is of critical interest in contemporary communication systems.  Such message security is particularly challenging to maintain in wireless communications systems, since the signal can propagate widely and hence is readily intercepted.  Traditionally, cryptographic approaches have been employed to prevent the intercepted signal from being decoded by the eavesdropper who lacks the cryptographic key, but intercepted messages can be stored and decoded in the future with emerging algorithmic and computational advances, or after the key is compromised.  As an alternative, information-theoretic secrecy techniques provide everlasting security that prevents the adversary from observing a signal from which the message can ever be extracted; however, information-theoretic secrecy relies on an advantage in the physical environment for the intended recipient over the adversary.  For example, in an unobstructed environment, it would require that the intended recipient be closer to the transmitter than the adversary. 

The main achievement of this project in Intellectual Merit has been to develop a technique to provide information-theoretic secrecy in wireless communication environments, even when the adversary starts with an advantage in the physical environment over the intended recipient.  In the developed technique, the transmitter establishes a cryptographic key with the intended recipient and employs that key to introduce intentional distortions in the transmitted signal that are more easily removed at the receiver of the intended recipient than that of the adversary.  The adversary is assumed to store the distorted signal and then eventually obtain the key; however, due to conversion losses in the front-end of the adversary's receiver, it is not possible with this belated knowledge of the key for the adversary to extract the message from the stored signal.  Multiple instantiations of this approach have been developed under this project, with the most robust being an approach where the transmitter adds Gaussian jamming to the transmitted signal according to the key.  Numerical results demonstrate that information-theoretic secrecy can be obtained in such a scenario, even when the eavesdropper has a significant advantage in the physical environment for receiving the signal versus the intended recipient.

This core technique has been extended in multiple directions:

1.  Exploiting a co-channel radar:  Due to the crowded radio spectrum, the coexistence of communication and radar systems in the same bandwidth has attracted significant attention.  In this project, the presence of a radar with a random waveform generated from the key is exploited to obtain the advantage for the intended recipient over the eavesdropper.  Numerical results indicate the utility of this approach, even in the presence of small errors in cancelling the radar signal at the intended recipient.

2.  Minimum energy secure networks:  The technique has been extended beyond the construction from the point-to-point scenario, where only a single transmission is required by the transmitter to reach the intended recipient, to multi-hop networks.  In multi-hop networks, the key contribution was the development of computationally-efficient approaches to minimum energy secure routing in networks that are robust to the (generally unknown) location of the passive eavesdroppers.

Finally, the project has developed two major extensions of the main line of work:

1.  Location privacy:  An information-theoretic notion of perfect location privacy in the asymptotic limit of a large number of system users has been developed.   Anonymization and obfuscation are used as location privacy protection mechanisms to hide the identity of users over time.  The strongest adversary is assumed:  one that has complete statistical knowledge of the users' movement patterns.   The adversary's goal is to use this knowledge to de-anonymize the users and thus obtain their location data.  The focus of the project has been to consider the number of observations required by an adversary to break a user's privacy.

2.  Detecting signal processing:  Techniques from this project have been employed to determine whether a signal has been recorded and then replayed.  This will have an impact on radar spoofing, where an enemy records the signal, delays it, and then plays it back to fool the radar about the range, or in standard replay attacks in security.   The key idea is to detect small nonlinearities inherently involved in the process, in particular establishing the conditions for when it can be detected whether a signal has been quantized.

The Broader Impacts of this project have affected society and the development of a diverse workforce.  Advances in the provisioning of security in wireless communications systems, which are ubiquitous in modern society, has the potential to impact people's everyday lives.  Towards this advancement, this project offers an alternative method for protecting messages from eavesdropping.  The project has also resulted in the training of a diverse collection of four undergraduate and six graduate student researchers; in particular, four female Ph.D. students and one female undergraduate student worked on the project.
